thread.title: Being in the navy in Plymouth has been the best start for global tech firm - Devon Live

author: Hannah Finch
title: Being in the navy in Plymouth has been the best start for global tech firm - Devon Live
text:
News Being in the navy in Plymouth has been the best start for global tech firm Computech is the headline sponsor of the Western Morning News Business Awards. It creates business management software that competes against large players, such as SAP, Microsoft, NetSuite, SalesForce and Sage. It’s been a good year for Garry Thompson, boss of Saltash software development firm Computech .
The business has been named amongst the top export firms in this year’s Western Morning News Business Awards and that follows its recognition for its global sales with the Queen’s Award for International Trade in 2017.
It is a small firm with global ambitions - seven out of eight of Computech’s biggest clients are based 5,000 miles away in the United States.
Mr Thompson, said: “People ask me why have you got so much business in the States and my honest answer is that I don’t know.
"It’s probably down to the fact that I’m on the phone at all hours. I make myself available to those customers who are five to eight hours behind. They seem to like our product, which in itself, is quite unique, offering them capabilities which would be very difficult to find in other products in the business management software arena.” Read More The 2018 tech list - 30 amazing firms you need to know about in Devon and Cornwall
Mr Thompson, 62, says I don’t consider myself a salesman. He said: “When you know and believe in a product, your enthusiasm sells it. I know that because I originally built it to meet my needs and I just demonstrate its capabilities. I have some very clever guys who now work for me, turning my dreams into a reality and taking us forward to meet the challenges of the future.” Watch why Computech is headline sponsor of the Western Morning News Business Awards Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
And it is paying off for the business that has a number of clients, based on long-term relationships.
And there can’t be many businesses with clients that invite their software suppliers to stay in a condo in Texas and go horse riding on the beautiful beaches of the Gulf of Mexico.
But it is testament to the client base that Computech has built up over the years.
Mr Thompson said: “My philosophy is to treat people as you would like to be treated yourself. I know it sounds corny, but it is absolutely true and it is a good principle to have, both in life and business.”
Originally born from a business building PCs, Garry hit upon software development when he started to write a package that could help manage his own business. So impressed were his clients by the software that could manage and record every stage of the business process, from prospective customer through to goods dispatch, that they started to ask for the same. Read More From gin to yachts and something ver...
At the time, the team were building bespoke software for all kinds of customers, from recruitment companies to large scale distributors.
He said: “It was around 2007, and I was just expanding, moving into new offices into Saltash and taking on more people. But then the recession hit. We finished two big projects in 2007 and then there were just little trickles of work, companies had little money and nobody was spending.”
If they say innovation is the brainchild of necessity then the 2008 recession was it. Rather than rely on making bespoke software for individual businesses, Garry decided to bring together all the individual elements he had developed to create one consolidated package. And then, BusinessMan was born.
The business management system- which, crucially, can be tweaked to suit any business - has been a massive driver of growth.
It competes successfully against the large players, such as SAP, Microsoft, NetSuite, SalesForce and Sage.
From 2014/2015 to this year sales have grown from £400,000 to more than £900,000.
As part of the global expansion, Computech plans to open an office in the USA and will pursue similar ventures in the Far East and Australasia. Garry Thompson, MD at Computech
He said: “We are a global business and technology means that we can do business anywhere.”
As a headline sponsor for this year’s Western Morning News Business Awards, Mr Thompson said it is vital to celebrate the achievements of South West businesses and we should be shouting loudly about what the region has to offer. Western Morning News Business Awards 2018: The Shortlist

This will be awarded to a profitable, growing business that has a positive impact on the Westcountry’s economy as a whole.
The Cornish Bakery , Paulton
SMALL BUSINESS OF THE YEAR sponsored by Thomas Westcott
Open to all organisations with no more than 50 employees, this award will recognise the small business that has maintained consistent growth and strong financial performance.
Salcombe Distilling Co. , Salcombe
YOUNG BUSINESS PERSON OF THE YEAR sponsored by Cornwall College Business
This award is open to young entrepreneurs aged 30 and under (as of November 2017) who have shown flair, resilience and wisdom beyond their years.
Katherine George, Oh So Social , Penryn
Becky Veater, Elixel , Plymouth
Tom Wadsworth, Bad Wolf Horizon , Helston

This award will be made to the company that demonstrates a commitment to continuously improving its standards of customer service.
The Old Vicarage , Otterton

BEST TECHNOLOGICAL OR CREATIVE BUSINESS sponsored by Vodafone
The judges are looking for an outstanding business from the creative and technological industry sectors.
Sponge UK , Plymouth
BEST BUSINESS START UP sponsored by LiveWest
Judges will be interested in the ethos and background to the business, its profitability as well as what difference it has made in its sector since it started trading and how it has overcome any challenges it has encountered.
Swaz , Plymouth

The ‘Made in Britain’ stamp has always been a mark of quality and this award seeks to recognise the Westcountry businesses that are making great things.
Rittal , Plymouth
COMMUNICATION AWARD sponsored by Byron D Hobbs

Thomas Westcott Chartered Accountants , Exeter
MICRO BUSINESS OF THE YEAR sponsored by Highwater Sails
Our Micro Business of the Year will be a company of 2-9 people that has demonstrated strong revenue growth and a product or service of a quality that stands above competitors.
EXPORTER OF THE YEAR
This award rewards an organisation that has generated substantial and sustained increases in export activity.
The judges will consider what makes the winning company different to their competitors, the level of export and the products or service exported.
St Austell Brewery , St Austell
LIFETIME ACHIEVEMENT AWARD sponsored by Browne Jacobson
This award will go to the businessman or woman who, in the opinion of the judges has made a considerable, profitable and lasting contribution to a business – and the region – over a period of at least 20 years.
The winner of this category is nominated by the judges and will be announced on the night.
He said: “We should be selling that strength for the South West. There’s no longer any need for tech business or financial services to be in the capital or the South East where it is expensive to live, get to work or rent premises.”
He said that the region should set its sights high, to become pioneers in the green revolution of smart cities, renewables and electric cars.
He said: “We are never going to be an industrial heartland but the south west does have massive potential to be hosts for leaders in technology. “We have small manufacturers and the region is ideal for that but we need the infrastructure to make the best of that.
“We lose out massively on spending per head on infrastructure compared to London and the only way to change that is devolution. We need to have the power to make the spending decisions for ourselves.”
And Garry has never been one to shy away from a challenge.
Brought up on a council estate on the Wirral, he left grammar school aged 15 to join the Royal Navy.
As a Chief Weapons Engineer specialising in electronics communications and radar, he was based in Plymouth and served for 17 years.
He said: “Being in the Royal Navy gives you a certain type of resilience because of the excellent training. Failure isn't an option. When you’re trying to fix a sonar system in the middle of the Indian ocean and the sea’s rough and you’re in compartment buried in the bowels of the ship with a sick bucket, there’s no one you can call. You have to fix this thing and that’s it. It teaches you that in life, you just have to get on with it and get the job done, that’s the only option.”
Computech employs 26 people, mostly with skills in software development. He has employed staff from across Europe including Italy, Latvia, Spain, Portugal, France and Germany as well the United States. Read More High-tech innovation centre will be EPIC for Torbay's potential
His company has also taken on computer programming apprentices, who have excelled in their roles.
Mr Thompson said he voted for Brexit and believes that the UK should be able to have sovereignty.
He said: “People say it’s about immigration but for me it is absolutely not. I think that people who apply for jobs here and meet the skills requirements, should be able to fill a vacancy here, whether they are from the EU or anywhere else.
"If we have a skills shortage, we are held back in our ambitions to better ourselves and the country as a whole. I also think freedom of movement, free trade, open borders and collaboration in research and security is absolutely essential but we do have to have control of our own destiny.”
And Computech has set its own business ambitions for the years ahead, with plans to grow its UK customer base and bring in more clients from the South West. Like us on Facebook
